body.p: Paul Garras, Started from Louisville to new Haven Ky, about the 21st of May 1860, to take possession of a grist mill leased from Jack Dawson W. Carden, & located on rolling fork. When he begun at Sd mill he had a capital of $1800; he employed in the Mill Erhard Duplain and Anthony Julian, the former is a carpenter by trade, and the other (^as a Journeyman^) was in 1862, employed as a cook for Col. Grose, of the 36th Regt Indiana Vol. (now deceased). Chs Vander Espt was living at the time temporarily with P. Garras, and remained with him, until he left, which was towards the 18th or 20th of April 1861.

As to the intimacy said to be existing between Garras and the Colored girl Cirilla, a slave of Jack Dawson of New Haven afd, it is known She was washing for Paul Garras, and his hands, Sd Dawson, knew it, on the 21st of Dec. 1860 Vander Espt got married, and occupied a rooom in Garras' House where the aford slave frequently called on Mrs Vander Espt to learn the making of her own dresses, about the 1st day of April Erhard Duplain referred above made a trunk for Vander Espt, to pack in his books, which being too small was voluntarily given to Sd Cirilla to put her clothes in. Consequently P. Garras did not order the trunk, neither did he Stole the clothes & Jewellery of Sd Slave, as represented on the Indictment issued by the Nelson Circuit Court, under date of May 1st 1861, this is a feeble effort on the part of Dawson, and perfectly untrue, in as much as it can be proved that Garras never intended to run off the Girl aford. The trunk
at the application of the Girl Cirilla was sent to Mrs widow Hay, Dry Goods dealer, of that locality, not far from the dwelling of J Dawson, this being from fear that her master would not allow her to retain the trunk at home, it was not intended for a mean purpose, as mentioned in the Indictment. P. Garras, furnished flour and lumber to Sd J. Dawson & to his Sons amongst whom, was Wm who owed Garras a certain amount of money, which was never paid Garras intending to go to little Rock Ark., This vexed Dawson's family, and without any Just a cause, accused Garras of attempting to run away with Sd Slave. In this case, Mr. Lowell H. Rousseau was the defendor of the accused, when called into the army, he could not go and attend to this case. Shortly after the arrival of Garras in Louisville, he was arrested by policeman Kirk Patrick, and taken back to New Haven, where an infuriated mob would have hanged the accused had it not been for the intervention of Some friends, his life would have been in danger Having spent his hard earnings, and having no work in Louisville, he went to Memphis, and probably is now in its vicinity, occupied as a Mill wright; the difficulty of corresponding then, from Lousiville to Memphis, previous to the taking of this latter place, is probably the cause by which his securities were obliged to pay considering the impossiblity of the accused to appear in Court. The character of Garras is good, there as some ways & means on the Indictments, which in
some respects, seems incomprehensible. Herein went Secy By pure humanity. It is well to represent that many persons are indebted to P Garras in New Haven perhaps it was the cause which prompted his debtors, named therein to accuse him of larceny, as represented on the Indictments whereof.

Louisville Ky September 21st 1863
Chas. J. Vander Espt
Vice Counsul of Belgium
State of Kentucky
Jefferson County.
Charles J. Vander Espt states that he believes the satements contained in the foregoing and above the indictments of Paul Garis, to be true

Chas J. Vander Espt
Sworn to before me by Charles J. Vander Espt this 22 day of September 1863
Jeff Brunn
Notary Public Jeff Co Ky.
